Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Determining the drivers of annual methane emissions in temperate wetlands
Award.AbstractNarration:
Wetlands are the largest natural sources of the potent greenhouse gas methane. Production of methane in wetlands can be fueled by a range of carbon substrates, including organic matter recently derived from plant material and organic matter that has been stored in the soil for many years. The relative contributions of old and young carbon substrates to methane emissions are not well constrained but may impact whether wetland ecosystems accelerate or mitigate future climate changes. This project will use field measurements and controlled laboratory experiments to determine seasonal changes in the carbon sources that fuel methane production in a wetland in the Sacramento Delta, California; formerly the largest region of freshwater wetlands in the western United States. The study site is characteristic of highly seasonal temperate wetlands. Natural gradients will be used to explore ecological and meteorological drivers of methane dynamics.

This research will provide rare and valuable data on seasonal variation of carbon sources for methane production in a wetland environment. The work will also take place in the broader context of wetland restoration in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta, California, where 150 years of land drainage has led to extreme land subsidence, very large greenhouse gas emissions, and a range of other hydrological and ecological issues. Public and private agencies will be engaged to translate the scientific results of this project into information for public stakeholders and agencies concerned with the future of the Delta. A specific outcome of collaboration will be to provide assistance with the development of a wetland restoration protocols to quantify and minimize methane emissions in delta ecosystems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wetland ecosystems feature spatial heterogeneity in canopy height, plant species, and soil drainage that present challenges to estimating and scaling greenhouse gas exchange. Combing flux measurements at different scales is a promising methodological approach that we developed and applied in this research. Specifically,  we combined spatially-explicit chamber measurements with continuous, field-scale, eddy-covariance observations to estimate wetland fluxes of the three most important greenhouse gases: carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide. The approach permitted quantitative partitioning of gas fluxes – and their associated radiative forcing effects - between open-water pools and vegetated zones. One key finding was that zones of emergent vegetation accounted for >90% of wetland methane emissions, while the overall radiative forcing effect of greenhouse gas emissions was larger for open-water zones, due to high rates carbon dioxide emission. A second important outcome of the study was that the highest nitrous oxide fluxes occurred during the colder winter months. These data support a recent paradigm shift away from simple temperature response functions for gas flux predictions that are often used for carbon dioxide and methane, but that often breakdown in the face of nitrous oxide dynamics. Instead, the asynchronous fluxes of oxygen-sensitive methane and nitrous oxide gases suggest seasonal wetland oxygen demand oscillations can be important in regulating the composition of wetland greenhouse gas emissions and that fluxes may be better represented by models that balance oxygen supply and consumption explicitly.

 

Vegetation plays a central role in ecosystem gas exchange. In wetlands, emergent plants typically dominate carbon dioxide uptake, while they also act as a conduit and substrate source for methane release. The net radiative forcing effect of these opposing fluxes is still highly uncertain, as is the respective contributions of recently fixed carbon versus bulk peat carbon in wetland decomposition. We developed the capability for radiocarbon isotope analysis of methane. We used radiocarbon to distinguish the carbon substrate sources for wetland methane production, and related spatial and temporal variability to emergent plant presence and activity. The approach exploited the large contrast in isotopic composition of bulk wetland organic matter with atmospheric carbon dioxide used for present photosynthesis, which is a legacy of drainage in the Sacramento Delta, California. We collected samples from the sediment bubble inventory in open-water and vegetated zones, as well as gas from plant-stems, over one year. We tested and utilized a new vacuum line for the cryogenic isolation of methane from mixed air samples for accelerator mass spectrometry radiocarbon analysis. The results demonstrated that seasonality in autotrophic productivity and temperature drives wetland carbon dynamics and, using an isotopic mixing model, we found that proximity to emergent vegetation stimulated methane production from recently fixed carbon sources, and that this effect varied seasonally with cycles of plant phenology.
